description: The course provides an introduction to Discourse and Grammar – an interdisciplinary branch of language study comprising research from typology, syntax, interactional linguistics, and cognitive science. The course takes Discourse and Grammar as the label for a unified field which looks at discourse from the perspective of grammar, and grammar from the perspective of discourse. The Discourse and Grammar approach is interested in finding functional explanations behind the emergence of grammar. Discourse is understood as the domain of language use, with speakers making functional choices at all levels of structure, whether across sentence and larger unit boundaries, inside clauses and phrases, or even within words. Grammar provides the structures for linguistic action, and functionally motivated linguistic action in turn produces the recurrent patterns that ultimately grammaticize, giving rise to linguistic structure. The course will cover the two major directions of the interface between grammar and interaction: (1) how grammatical structures arise from fluid patterns of language use (discourse); (2) how stable structures of grammar provide templates for linguistic action. Research questions in the domain of Discourse and Grammar can be addressed through a variety of methods, including quantitative (corpus linguistics, psycholinguistics experiments) and qualitative (Conversation Analysis, discourse analysis, structural analysis).
title: Discourse and Grammar

description: Advanced Microeconomics covers more advanced topics in macro economics. The second part explores advanced topics in auctions, mechanism design, and strategic communication under incomplete information. It begins with auction theory, first-price and second-price auctions, revenue equivalence, and optimal mechanism design. It then examines dynamic games of incomplete information, introducing Perfect Bayesian Equilibrium and its applications to signaling games. Other applications include job market signaling (Spence), adverse selection (Akerlof’s Market for Lemons), strategic information disclosure, and cheap talk models. Finally, the course explores herd behavior, Bayesian persuasion, and advanced monopoly pricing strategies, including price discrimination and its limitations.

description: Social reform is an organized collective effort to restructure culturally accepted norms and improve various spheres of society often focusing on issues like inequality, poverty, education, labor rights, and family violence. Since the onset of industrialization in Europe, reform groups have employed statistical data to expose the social conditions they aspired to eradicate. Further urbanization, economic and population expansion, internal migration and the increasing public interest to social issues all make it essential today to understand statistics and machine learning from a sociological perspective. This course offers an overview of most popular statistical and machine learning methods including exploratory data analysis, model diagnostics, comparative and longitudinal modeling, dimensionality reduction and clustering techniques. With the use of R notebooks and log files, students will engage in hands-on data exploration and feature engineering, apply code, fit and critically evaluate models, and interpret the results through a sociological lens.
title: Statistics and Machine Learning for Social Reform

Key themes addressed include power, con cooperation and interdependence, and political economy. Our primary goal throughout this course will be to lay the theoretical and analytical foundations for the study of international politics. In order to do so, we shall examine several theoretical approaches in IR that seek to answer important research questions and puzzles in international politics.
title: International Relations Theory

description: The course will cover microeconomic aspects of international trade. It will introduce the standard models of the theory of international trade: The Ricardian model, where trade is driven by the comparative advantage based on technological differences across countries, and the Heckscher-Ohlin model, where comparative advantage and trade are determined by the cross-country differences in the endowments of the factors of production. The course will also explore the new theories of international trade based on the increasing returns to scale and offshoring. The international trade policy issues discussed in the course will include tariffs, quotas, export subsidies, and international agreements on trade.
title: International Trade

description: This course provides an in-depth exploration of the Internet of Things (IoT) with a strong emphasis on programming embedded devices and deploying machine learning (ML) models on the edge. IoT systems consist of interconnected devices that sense their environment using a variety of sensors, process data locally or collaboratively, and communicate using protocols such as WiFi, LoRaWAN, and BLE. Students will learn real-time operating systems (RTOS), and low-power design strategies, gaining hands-on experience with microcontrollers such as ESP32, STM32, and RP2040. The course covers TinyML, focusing on deploying optimized machine learning models on resource-constrained devices for real-time inference. Additional topics include secure communication, and edge computing architectures. Through a mix of theoretical foundations and practical exercises, students will work on hardware programming, energy-efficient designs, wireless networking, and AI-driven IoT solutions. The course culminates in a final project, where students will develop an end-to-end IoT system integrating embedded computing and edge ML.
title: Internet of Things and Machine Learning on the Edge

pre_req: CSCI 333 Computer Networks (1145) (C- and above) AND ROBT 206 Microcontrollers with Lab (476) (C- and above)
description: This course introduces students to the fundamentals of the Internet of Things. The Internet of Things consists of devices which can sense their environment using sensors, can sometimes collaborate with each other, and report their findings through radio communication protocols. These interconnected devices offer exciting new services to improve people’s quality of lives and can be applied to various application domains such as smart cities, smart homes, smart agriculture, and industrial automation. In this course, an overview of the societal benefits of the Internet of Things is provided along with the basic understanding of the main components of Internet of Things networks at all levels of abstraction from the physical layer up to the application layer. Topics include smart sensing, wireless communications and propagation, media access control layer protocols, routing protocols, and application layer protocols. The course balances the theory with practice introducing hands-on exercises, small team projects, and project presentations.
title: Internet of Things: Technologies and Applications

description: The first part focuses on classical theories of consumer and producer behavior, market demand and supply, and on the theory of competitive equilibrium. Topics include, before the fall break, utility maximization by price-taking consumers and cost minimization and profit maximization by competitive firms; market interaction of aggregate demand and aggregate supply and the properties of a perfectly competitive general equilibrium. The second part of the course explores decision-making under uncertainty and the principles of game theory dealing with strategic situations in which decision-makers’ payoffs depend not only on their own choices but also on the choices of others. We first introduce the expected utility theory and then delve into game theory, covering static and dynamic games to analyze market structures and different models of competition.

description:

It explores the areas of health promotion, physiologic changes associated with pregnancy, high risk conditions associated with pregnancy and the development of the fetus and newborn. Emphasis is on adaptation to the biopsychosocial needs of the childbearing family with sensitivity to the cultural needs and ethical issues of a diverse population. Critical thinking, problem solving, stress adaptation, role, family and nursing theories provide a major focus for understanding childbearing.

Clinical experiences reflect a diversity of settings including outpatient, inpatient, and community programs that provide services to the childbearing family. The students’ ability to apply the nursing process, using critical thinking skills, is expanded through clinical activities. The clinical setting will provide collaboration opportunities with interdisciplinary health professionals to foster health promotion and restoration.

description: Pathophysiology –is the study of the disturbed physiological processes that cause, result from, or are otherwise associated with a disease or injury. Pathology is the medical discipline that describes conditions typically observed during a disease state, whereas physiology is the biological discipline that describes processes or mechanisms operating within an organism. Pathology describes the abnormal or undesired condition, whereas pathophysiology seeks to explain the functional changes that are occurring within an individual due to a disease or pathologic state. The course will introduce students to the pathogenesis of different diseases and potential pharmacological targets. Subject includes physiology and pathophysiology of cardiovascular, pulmonary, renal, gastrointestinal systems, neuroscience, immunology.
title: Organ System and Common Diseases

description: This course provides an introduction to parallel programming with an emphasis on applications in scientific computing. Topics include an overview or relevant aspects of the hardware for parallel computer systems and parallel programming models (shared memory, distributed memory, and GPU-based computing), performance considerations, parallel algorithms, scalability, and code optimization techniques. Practical exercises will involve hands-on experience with using common libraries and software stacks for parallel computations, such as OpenMP (multithreading), MPI (message passing), and CUDA/OpenCL (GPU computing) in high-performance computing environments. The course is suitable for students interested in computational science and data-intensive research.

Topics include the architecture of parallel computing systems, parallel programming models (shared memory, distributed memory, and GPU-based computing), performance optimization, load balancing, and scalability. Emphasis is placed on practical implementation using industry-standard parallel computing frameworks, including OpenMP (multithreading), MPI (message passing), and CUDA/OpenCL (GPU computing). Students will gain hands-on experience running and optimizing parallel code on high-performance computing systems, with applications relevant to computational sciences.
title: Parallel Programming for Scientific Computing

description: This course is intended for master’s students interested in the efficient use of modern parallel systems. Topics such as parallel computer architecture, programming models, memory hierarchy, parallel program design and parallel programming tools for multi-core systems and general-purpose graphics processing units (GPGPUs) will be covered. This comprehensive overview will equip students with a broad understanding of the key approaches in heterogeneous programming. Students will engage in practical, hands-on projects utilizing real-world scientific models to tackle contemporary challenges and applications, including physics, chemistry, biology and trustworthy machine learning. In the second part, the course covers the most common and current GPU parallel programming techniques with lab-based programming assignments using CUDA API with C/C++ and Python.

description: This course is labeled Philosophy AND Tragedy to reflect a dual concern with art and human life. First, we shall study the philosophy of the art of tragedy, examining the nature of tragic works as such and inquiring into the cognitive, emotional, moral, and political values distinctive of tragedy. Second, the course will look to tragedy to inform philosophical problems of human existence. These include such problems as human agency amid weakness of will; the conflict between moral and political values; the limits of rationality and the liberation of liminal experiences (such as religious and ritual ecstasy). Both our aims require a substantive engagement with tragedy; to that end, tragic works themselves will figure on the syllabus (e.g., by Aeschylus, Sophocles, and Euripides, or perhaps other authors); we hope to include more contemporary literary works. Philosophers on the syllabus include, variously, Plato, Aristotle, Hume, Schopenhauer, Nietzsche, Nussbaum.

description:
This course explores the logic and limits of causal inference in the social sciences, confronting the foundational challenge that causal relationships cannot be directly observed or logically deduced from empirical regularities alone.
We will critically examine the misuse of p-values, the problem of false positives, model overfitting, and post hoc hypothesis testing. Students will develop a clear understanding that research design, not statistical significance or p-hacking, determines the credibility of causal claims. We explore how data can both reveal and obscure the truth, depending on how it is collected, modeled, and interpreted. 
Rather than relying on abstract theoretical exposition, the course is grounded in applied case studies from economics, political science, and public policy.

This course familiarizes the students with the major current methods of analytical chemistry, focusing on those methods that employ the interaction of electromagnetic radiation or ions/electrons with the matter as well as modern instrumental methods of separation, such as chromatography.  The course will not only give students a comprehensive overview of spectroscopic, spectrometric, and microscopic methods of analysis but also make them aware of up-to-date limitations, challenges, and perspectives in those areas. 
Briefly, the course will include the following topics according to its syllabus. Measurements. Signal to noise and sources of noise Calibration methods: external standards, standard addition, and internal standards. Figures of Merits in spectroscopic methods. Electromagnetic spectrum. Principles of operation and key parts of spectrometers and photometers: light sources, wavelength selectors, detectors. Atomic spectroscopy from flame and electrothermal to plasma (ICP) atomization. Molecular spectroscopy methods:  UV-vis, fluorescence, IR (transmittance and ATR modes), Raman/SERS. Single and double beam instruments.  Mass spectrometry: the versatile, selective, and very sensitive method used from elemental analysis to analysis to biofluids (blood, urine, etc). Surface analysis, surface spectroscopy, and high resolutions microscopy: XPS, Auger, SPR, SEM, AFM, etc. Modern chromatography, the queen of separations. Gas chromatography and liquid chromatography /HPLC: parameters, columns, and detectors, examples of application. Individual presentation of the analytical spectroscopic method and impactful research publication about this method.
title: Spectrochemical Methods of analysis

In the first part of the course (until week 6), we introduce fundamental concepts of quantitative analysis (variables and hypothesis), discuss the logic of quantitative studies, and cover the basics of a programming language (R or Python). We discuss a variety of descriptive graphs, measurements (frequency and dispersion), and tests (tests for independence, distribution) for monofactorial analysis. description: Heritage is a global matter. In the broadest sense, heritage includes both the tangible and intangible elements of cultures—languages, local history and archaeology, special technologies, traditional arts and performances, architecture, cultural practices and beliefs. Such diverse areas are enriched by incorporating insights from multiple disciplines, such as anthropology, archaeology, history, museum studies, political science, public policy, human geography, and others. Now more than ever, academics and governments are supporting approaches which foster greater collaboration when it comes to heritage. Public heritage aims to bring together multiple voices from researchers, institutions, and public stakeholders to ensure a greater appreciation for and understanding of heritage. Learning how to make heritage meaningful to the public is key to its protection and preservation. This course aims to provide students with the opportunity to bridge the gap between academics and the community to have meaningful conversations about shared heritage and what its role might be in today’s world. Students will connect with local or international institutions, cultivate skills for communicating heritage matters, and develop their own heritage-specific projects to present publicly either on a digital platform or through an in-person event.
title: Applied Public Heritage
